OK I know I'm a bit late, but here's what the song really means to me. 

It is about a guy (him, you, me, anyone) who was never free to be himself. Instead, society forces us to adopt certain behaviours from the moment we were born. They tell us what's right or wrong, what's good or bad, whether legally (laws) or culturally (through the opinion of others). So the guy grows up and feels trapped and he can never escape from this prison. Then he just gives up. He doesn't care anymore and feels he might as well die right away since it's not he (the guy he was or could have been otherwise without all the social pressure he had to conform to) anymore who lives but some zombie who has had to live by society's standards. So in a sense, the unforgiven could refer to society as a whole.

But to me, the unforgiven also has a second meaning : himself. He is the Unforgiven because he can't forgive himself for not breaking free from all this crap and finding enough courage to be himself, to be the boy he could have been had he not surrendered to social pressure. Despite his vow to never surrender (that never from this day his will they'll take away), he failed. Then he gives up the fight, he feels old, and he feels his life is over (I don't think the lyrics litterally mean he grew old. That's just how he feels.) He feels there's nothing more to expect from life. (The old man then prepares to die regretfully) What's the point in living if he could never be himself anyway? For him it's too late. He can't forgive society for forcing its rules upon him, nor can he forgive himself for not having fought harder to break free from this when he was younger.

I'd like to say I really like this song before I dive into my super negative interpretation of this song. The lyrics are so meaningful. I love how Hetfield growls when the song's about anger and injustice, and then how it becomes so tender and melodious when the song's about despair or love. The guitar makes this song even more wonderful. 

"Unforgiven" is about damnation. According to Christianity, God forgave people their sins by giving us salvation through the sacrifice and resurrection of his son, Jesus. If not for God's forgiveness, people everywhere would all be damned to hell because we all sin and our sin would stain the spotless and perfect heaven. "So I dub thee unforgiven" is a reference to religion, and means that the man is dubbed as damned. 

The man is condemned because he spent his childhood slaving after abusive people. Instead of appreciating his obedience, they took advantage of it, making him bleed ("New blood joins the earth...") and stripping him his will, thoughts, freedom, and individuality. His need to please to escape pain prevented him from breaking free and experiencing happiness. He pleases his abusers grudgingly (Never shined through in what I've shown). By pleasing harsh conformity, he never knows the freedom to be individual and happy for himself. (Never free/ Never me) (You labeled me/ I'll label you)

He becomes "this bitter man he is" because he bitterly regrets that he never opposed his oppressors who exploited his passiveness and stole away his freedom of being his own person.

He never felt the happiness of possessing that freedom. He can't forgive himself because of the bitterness and self-loathing for not fighting back. There is no happiness in hell, of course. When the man was a boy, he knew no joy, and as a man he still doesn't know much about joy.

It's a very sad song. It's true you can go deeper than what's on the surface and see this song as a long metaphor about the misery of current society, but I'd rather not do that.

This song is one of the most beautiful rock songs to ever grace us. This is a story, so if you can't imagine the meaning, I will take you through the meaning now.

The song opens with a dramatic melody, and allows us to know that this is a sad song, but not why.

With James's first vocals, we understand that there's a new life to earth. This boy doesn't learn the rules of life like a child with entitlement, but he learns life through punishment. He becomes the whipping boy of his masters. Never is he allowed to think for himself, but to serve.

Then we reach James's beautiful chorus. What this boy has felt, thought, and imagined could have changed everything. All of the amazing things he dreamed were never shown in his actions, which makes this song even more sad, because we all have something more in us that we never show. If you know the history of Metallica, then you understand where the ties to his mother and religion come in(no, I'm an atheist, but that's where HE is coming from.)

Next verse is his true submission. He tries to live up to his masters, thought he doesn't love what he does, and he understands that his calling is out there. He wants to go further in his life, but in his dystopian nightmare, they control his life. Towards the end of his verse, James tells us that this isn't a fictional character, but instead a biographical look into his own life.
